I've executed manually this process. The behavior is the same. The delay introduced does not add any significant time excess. The number of HA routers does not affect to this delay.

As I commented before, this patch will add a deterministic delay when transitioning to master. In this case, when a router is created and becomes master, this delay will be present.

But this delay will not scale with the number of routers, if this is the question here. It doesn't matter the number of HA routers present. This delay will be always constant.

neutron/agent/l3/agent.py.message: Actually, if we do not use the ResourceProcessingQueue, such call order reversing does not solve the main problem of the race condition. Other thread (greenlet) may get router info before line 546 running, and then here l3 agent still run router deleting and other run ha_state_change functions.

The L3NATAgent processes the routers updates in the main loop function "_process_router_update". This function retrieves the messages only from ResourceProcessingQueue.

The behavior you are describing is more possible with the current implementation. The delete execution, called in "ri.delete()", is the most time consuming process. With the base implementation, what you are describing can happen but not with the solution I'm proposing. During the deletion process, the agent cache does not have the router information anymore and this router can't be updated during this process; this is an improvement from the base code.

Regardless of the rest of the code introduced by this patch, this modification should be included in the code.

NOTE: because many workers can update at the same time the same router, a blocking mechanism should be implemented to avoid this, using the same agent router cache used to retrieve the router information.

neutron/agent/l3/ha.py.message: nit: this could be IMO named '_transition_states' or something like that

Allow me to recall my former change here again (I comment this once in your another patch): https://review.opendev.org/#/c/275614/

A queue introduced here, which means there will be a delay for state change. And this queue is not that L3 agent RouterProcessQueue (ResourceProcessingQueue). So the race condition mentioned in 275614 will still can be encontered: when a HA router is doing the state change, the _transition_states delay some time (maybe the lock wait time), and L3 agent is concurrently deleting the router. Line 171 to 177 can be run after the router is deleted, and some stale resource may be left forever.

This patch introduces a delay in the transition from "backup" to "master".

You are right, during this waiting period, the router can be deleted or could be in the process of being deleted.

The router deletion process is called from the L3 agent, L3NATAgent._safe_router_removed() -->  L3NATAgent._router_removed(). In this last function:
- The ns is deleted.
- The router DB entry is deleted
- The router cache in the agent (self.router_info) is deleted

This last step should be done first in order to clean the agent cache and, in case the router is deleted during the waiting period, hit L158 (exit because ri is None).

I'll propose a new PS.
Maybe I'm missing something, I do not see the new_state param was used in the caller? Then how this _transition_states is filled up?

Another race condition is happening when a HA router is deleting. A router notification is processed first in the 'master' node, and the 'VRRP' process will be dropped first, but in 'backup' node the 'VRRP' process may still run. Then a VRRP re-election causes such state change here. IMO, this delay may reduce the probability of such racing. But again, we need some test to prove that.

There are two scenarios here:
- State change from master to backup. This method does not change the current behavior. The state change will be applied immediately.

- State change from backup to master. In this case a delay is introduced between the state change reception and the state change execution. If during this time the router is deleted (or is being deleted), as commented in [1], the agent cache will delete the router entry during the deletion process. If succeeded, the cache will keep this register deleted; in case of exception, the register will be written again. 


This code is improving the current behavior and preventing a collision between commands in the same router.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/672568/6/neutron/agent/l3/agent.py

trove/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/version.message: Why to we need these information ? Shouldn't we just delete the row ?

1. I see most of the other trove db resources have those fields.
2. Keeping deleted items in the database would be helpful for debuging, auditing, etc.

Since a single instance may have multiple ports and each port may have multiple security groups assigned, the proposed table structure does not comply with database normalization principles [1] and causes data redundancy.

We should consider normalizing the table. For example, we could introduce the following structure:

Table "ports" for storing references to remote Neutron ports:

 id: remote Neutron port ID

Table "security_group_port_associations" for storing associations between ports and security groups:

 id: internal UUID
 security_group_id: foreign key from table "security_groups" 
 port_id: foreign key from table "ports"

Table "port_instance_associations" for storing associations between ports and Trove instances:

 id: internal UUID
 port_id: foreign key from table "ports"
 instance_id: ID of Trove instance

Also, in that case, we should consider dropping the table "security_group_instance_associations" since we implement the intermediate layer of abstraction - ports. Having security groups associated with ports we no longer need to associate security groups with instances.

I know that it seems to be much work, therefore I am opened to discussion and finding the pragmatic solution to the problem.

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_normalization#Satisfying_4NF

Following the approach adopted in the implementation of security groups extension [1], remote Neutron port ID should be treated as primary table ID.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/trove/blob/master/trove/extensions/security_group/models.py#L63

I don't think this is accurate.  I suggest changing this to:

  1.  Glance does not verify that the ``container_format`` image property accurately describes the image data payload.

The exact format of the compressed file is unspecified.  It is the responsibility of the consuming service to analyze the data payload and determine the compression format. ironic/drivers/modules/deploy_utils.py.message: Could we feasibly want to skip the current step without having rebooted? e.g. if we trigger an async action in the agent and wait for a callback.

nit: would be a little more readable to use a dict here, e.g.

cleaning = {'reboot': 'cleaning_reboot', 'skip': 'skip_current_clean_step'}
Not sure whether True or False is the most intuitive default here. Anyone else?

So far we have mix of two types of async steps:-
1. Steps that perform reboot and want them to be re-ran
   reboot = True with skip_current_step = False
   These are majority. Ex: Redfish and iLO driver BIOS
   steps. ILO driver RAID steps. 

2. Steps that perform reboot and wait for the response 
   through some kind of periodic task.
   Ex: Drac driver RAID steps

This method is to be used only for async steps hence the 'reboot' flag needs to be 'True'. The skipping of step is somthing optional. I was in doubt, about right default value for it and used it based on [1]. It is to skip the step.
https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/ironic/conductor/manager.py#L1071-L1072

If the default values are confusing, we can choose not to provide any default value. WDYT?

Without thinking too much, false for both of them. But ?? Almost tempted to make it None so that it is explicitly specified...

i don't know, this will be used internally. Not sure if setting to one or the other will cause the most errors (if any) in the future...

None actually makes sense to me. If we're chaining steps then we wouldn't want to set *_reboot to false if it was previously set to true. Skip is less important because it only affects the current step.

hmm. I guess the only reason for trying to 'get it right' is in case some out-of-tree driver uses it, which will make it harder to change. Having said that, I guess the safest thing is to use None as default value.

I'm thinking of future IF we ever want to add more flags to this method, and/or if we ever don't want to set a flag. We can use the "None' as an indicator not to set the flag. And any future change won't break existing code.

And after all this discussion, I bet we won't ever need to modify this method in the future :)

Do we think that most async steps will require a reboot? If so, then it makes sense for the default to be True. I'm thinking False otherwise.

I must have missed where we decided to have cleaning_reboot and deployment_reboot. Or did I add this in? (Can't recall now). The current step is in internal info. Guess we could clean this up later. or not.
This is required for the steps that are performed out-of-band but needs a reboot to check the success/failure.

This looks like it might be incorrect.  We should have a string with the first ID value in 'id_attr'.  You are trying to check for a multi-valued LDAP attribute, so I think you would want to check how many items are in here instead:

My comment might be a bit unclear.  You are successfully extracting the first value of the ID attribute from the LDAP entry here at line 1309.  The check at line 1310 is supposed to check if you have multiple values in LDAP for the ID attribute, but you are checking the length of the first ID value.  I propose you do something like this:

  if search_result:
      if len(search_result[0][1][self.id_attr]) > 1:
          raise exception....
      else:
          return search_result[0][1][self.id_attr][0]

We really have 4 tests that should exercise this code:

1 - The successful case where the ID attribute is single-valued and exists in the DN.  This is very common, and should already be covered by some of the basic LDAP tests we have.

2 - The successful case where the ID attribute is single-valued and DOES NOT exist in the DN.  This is covered by your new 'test_get_id_from_dn' test in patch set 6.

3 - The successful case where the ID attribute is multi-valued, but one of those values exists in the DN.  While we can't reliably support multi-valued ID attributes, we already used a heuristic to check if the ID attribute is in the DN and to just use that value even if more values exist in the entry.  Your new code still handles this case, but we do not have test coverage for it.  Please add a test.

4 - The failure case where the ID attribute is multi-valued and DOES NOT exist in the DN.  In this case, an exception should be raised since we can't reliably determine the correct ID value to use.  You should cover this in your new 'test_raise_not_found_dn_for_multivalued_attribute_id' test in patch set 6, but the exception in that test seems wrong.  It currently looks for exception.NotFound, which means the LDAP entry wasn't even found.  I would expect us to hit exception.Conflict instead, thrown from line 1311 here in this file.
good catch, I'm going to update this in a follow-up patch.

I don't think we should use this logic to determine the ID at all. It's rather inconsistent and unreliable as Nathan had indicated earlier. We should've always use search to determine the ID.

If memory serves, I didn't introduce this code btw. :-) I couldn't get rid of it fast enough because we were still supporting read/write LDAP at the time I believe. Maybe now is the *right time* to get rid of it.

Shouldn't the indexing here be protected with a try block that catches IndexError and KeyError? The IndexError is unlikely because python-ldap has returned a list with at least 1 2-tuple (because search result is non-empty). But it's entirely plausible you might get a KeyError on the id_attr.

I looked at the immediate callers and they don't appear to handle this exception directly. Is this handled somewhere else up the stack?

Also, we are going to be returning the search to the end user? If so, should we be doing that or should we just log it and return a less sensitive message?
Good catch, maybe ValueError should not be the right exception here, also I'm ok on just logging this as an invalid search query
What would this have done before if there were multiple values?

It would have returned the first value. Multiple values are not ordered so it would have been arbitrary which value was first. I see where you are going with this, it's a change in behavior, perhaps it's better to log a warning and continue to return the first value.

keystone/tests/unit/test_backend_ldap.py.message:
Good catch on a broken test.  The old test returned a value that wasn't even from the configured 'id' attribute!  Throwing an exception seems appropriate for this case.

I think you should add another variation on this test though.  We should test the case where a multi-valued 'id' attribute is present in the entry, but the DN of the entry has one of those 'id' values as the left-most RDN.  The code has logic to handle this case, as it will find that it has a multi-valued attribute and will then fall-back to checking for the 'id' in the DN.  You can just duplicate this test (renaming it of course), but modify the DN to be 'mail=<email1 UUID value>'.  The test can then check for these results:

        user_ref = PROVIDERS.identity_api.get_user(email1)
        self.assertEqual(email1, user_ref['id'])
It totally makes sense add another test scenario for it, I'll create this new test scenarios soon

It might be more appropriate to name this something like 'test_get_id_not_in_dn', as that is really what the test is doing.  In this case, the 'id' will be looked up from an attribute that is not in the DN.

I don't think it is a regression.  Basically, we had a workaround in the code that Guang added quite some time back where we just grab the leftmost attribute value from the DN and return it as the ID when we encounter a multi-valued ID attribute.  This is not great since it is not guaranteed to be the right ID, but it should be consistent and works around a corner case.  I think we should leave this functionality for backwards compatibility in case someone is depending on it.  We want to try to work when we encounter a multi-valued attribute, and the DN check logic allows that in limited cases.

The new exception comes in where the above heuristic was not working properly.  We were never checking that the value we pull out of the DN and return is actually the ID attribute!  If you look at the old version of this test, we use 'mail' as the ID attribute in LDAP.  The test was ensuring that the returned value is 'nobodycares', which is the value of the 'cn' attribute.  This is never correct, as it is not the ID attribute.  In fact, this behavior is the bug that Raildo is fixing here, as the incorrect ID will lead to things like incorrect group membership evaluation in Keystone.

What I was trying to say succinctly is this: If you don't specify a pool virt-install will manufacture one for you under the covers and use it as a favor. However, the virt-install manufactured pool is not known to oooq. During the clean up phase of oooq it will destroy resources it knows about (including the libvirt_volume_pool). But because the pool manufactured by virt-install is not present in the set of resources oooq will deallocate during clean up the pool is effectively orphaned and hence is a leaked resource.
I think you could write this in commit, we're not limited in commit length :) But up to you, not critical

I'm still trying to grasp how we'll do the provisioning initially vs once we call this effort complete. Would it be safe to say any of the following?

- Initially we'll bootstrap the cluster via ansible and some initial yamls based on system mode (simplex vs duplex)?

- We will still stage all the configuration in sysinv (cluster, tiers, backends (1 per tier), monitors, OSDs (per tier)) and grab that information as part of rook plugin(s) to generate overrides for the updated platform-integ-apps. When the app is applied it will update the cluster. Eventually this mechanism could be used to deploy the cluster and drop the ansible dependencies.

- Subsequent updates to the ceph related resources in sysinv would trigger a re-apply of the application.

- For future ceph configuration elements that we currently don't support, we could use chart overrides via the helm-overrides API to orchestrate cluster changes rather than updating sysinv code.
I think we want the couplings to sysinv to be minimal. It really should only be H/W related mappings (ceph-mon fs and OSD mappings to disks). Everything else should be via helm overrides.

In current implementation, the configuration of system-mode will transfer to sm to bring up ceph cluster in native env, and it will reflect some option such as replication of ceph monitors, and in Rook configuration there is also corresponding parameters, I will consider this in implementation of next phase.
The following 4 concerns reasonable and safe, and Rook operator can refresh the ceph cluster when check the configuration changed by override the yaml/helm charts and no need to update sysinv code for restful commands.

Please take a look at [1].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/kuryr-kubernetes/latest/installation/upgrades.html

 > 1. Do you mean to check if kuryr-k8s was used to create pods
 > previously or not? I mean if there pods with kuryr annotations?

I mean that I don't know when the SR-IOV stuff was introduced and I don't know if we already released that code you're modifying. We only support upgrading release-to-release, no deployments from trunk, so if you added the code doing annotations in previous format during the Train release, then we're fine to change that format as Train is not released yet.

I've made some kind of testing for describes scenario:
1. Run pod with sriov vif object of master branch  (old kuryr)
2. Upgrade kuryr (both on controller and CNI sides)
3. Try to delete previously created pod with sriov

What I've got from this experiment:
1. CNI catches an exception:
    NotImplementedError: Cannot load 'pod_link' in the base class

2. After 3 attempts k8s deletes a pod finally

I will start from the last point:
3. If we delete pods with vif objects in older version it is not necessary to take care about it on CNI side. But we should support this care somehow on controller side.
2. Good version. But how to register that kuryr was upgraded? Or we should create some kind of periodic task that will rewrite annotations constantly to the newest version? Or only when annotations will try to be get?
1. Do you mean to check if kuryr-k8s was used to create pods previously or not? I mean if there pods with kuryr annotations?

We need to think the other way around. Annotations are our database. They will be preserved between upgrades, e.g.:

1. User runs Kuryr that has VIFSriov 1.0, a bunch of pods gets created with those.
2. Kuryr gets fully upgraded and restarted.
3. User tries to delete those pods, Kuryr reads older annotations, fails and leaves some resources hanging.

That was my point, we should either:

1. Be sure that the code with previous version wasn't released (we can assume nobody run it then).
2. Provide a way to rewrite all the annotations (see that weird cmd/status.py).
3. Code defensively to be able to work even if fields are not present.

> I've made some kind of testing for describes scenario:
 > 1. Run pod with sriov vif object of master branch  (old kuryr)
 > 2. Upgrade kuryr (both on controller and CNI sides)
 > 3. Try to delete previously created pod with sriov
 > 
 > What I've got from this experiment:
 > 1. CNI catches an exception:
 > NotImplementedError: Cannot load 'pod_link' in the base class
 > 
 > 2. After 3 attempts k8s deletes a pod finally

It's only deleted because kubelet will finally just ignore CNI failure, but it means that we possible orphaned resources.

If this code gets an annotations in older format (from unupgraded kuryr-k8s-controller), then CNI will fail with an error:

    NotImplementedError: Cannot load 'pod_link' in the base class

Thus cluster should be upgraded starting from controller. It will allow to avoid such kind of errors.

Btw, from the other side , if kuryr-k8s-controller was upgraded and CNI wasn't upgraded, then CNI just will not parse an object and will notify that versions of objects are different:

    IncompatibleObjectVersion: Version 1.1 of VIFSriov is not supported, supported version is 1.0

kuryr_kubernetes/cni/daemon/service.py.message:
As described in doc for this patch it is necessary to run kubelet with additional argument to enable PodResources:

    KUBELET_EXTRA_ARGS="--feature-gates KubeletPodResources=true"

But there may be a situation when this argument is specified, but SriovBindingDriver is not used at all.

I think, you're right. It worth to create client only if we call it. Or we can create it if instance of Sriov Binding Driver is created (for example in __init__)

no, it was bad idea due to following reasons:
1. Instance of binding driver is been created only to vif computing and been deleted right after binding was completed.
2. Instance of binding driver is been created also for unbinding.and will be deleted as well
3. It means that setup function for pod resource client will be called many times. A lot of instances of client will be created, and the previous ones will be deleted.

Generally it creates an additional load. So it worth to leave setup of pod resource client here, in kuryr_kubernetes/cni/daemon/service.py so that it will be called once for period of CNI work

Ilya thanks for comments.
In this case I think the only one casse we can optimize is when PodResources is enabled and user doesn't try to use SRIOV.
For this case it worth to move initialization of PodResources client into initialization of sriov binding driver.
sure, but enabled multivif driver doesn't guarantee that exactly sriov driver will be used

My 2 cents:
clients.setup_pod_resources_client() will never fail, because gRPC client properly handles the missing unix socket case. Failure will happen if you'll try to use it, i.e. if you will try to get the list of pod resources.
Another point is that, IMHO, we should not allow using SRIOV if pod-resources is not available because this will lead to unpredictable device assignments as described in the bug.
So,
* if user has PodResources disabled (or kubelet version < 1.13) and doesn't try to use SRIOV, everything will be fine.
* if user has PodResources disabled and will try to use SRIOV, there will be gRPC exception and CNI will fail the port binding. Isn't it a normal behavior?
* if user has PodResources enabled and doesn't try to use SRIOV, everything is fine. Just a slight memory overhead on gRPC client.
* if user has PodResources enabled and will try to use SRIOV, this is our main case, everything should be OK.

Sure, sure, but we now support multiple deployment tools that deploy Kuryr - e.g. openshift-ansible and openshift/installer, Magnum in the future. We cannot expect them to enable PodResources server, especially as we support OpenShift 3.11, which is based on K8s 1.11, which haven't had that feature according to [1].

We need to make sure enablement of KubeletPodResources is totally optional.

[1] https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/command-line-tools-reference/feature-gates/

I have a feeling I asked about that in another review but can't find that at the moment. Generally I don't like creating it unconditionally as I'm not sure if it'll always work (kubelet is run in various configurations, e.g. in containers, also isn't that PodResources server an option to kubelet command?).

Would it be possible to just create it on first call to get_pod_resources_client()?

Do you mean that user can try to use sriov functionality without using k8s version >= 1.13 and face problems?
Let's suppose that we try to setup pod_resources_client in first it's call in SriovBindingDriver.
1. If k8s version >= 1.13 then it's ok
2. If k8s version < 1.13 and k8s has not feature according then obviously clients.setup_pod_resources_client() will fail.

So what do you suggest? How to ensure that feature is enabled?
Maybe try to check version of k8s and check kubelet's arguments?

yes, but at least the opposite is true, right? If the multivif is not enabled, SRIOV will not be used, right?

Perhaps Michal has a better idea here

I think this is a right place for clients initialization.
Actually, functionality of pod_resources_client is used in Sriov binding driver only.
Do you think it worth to add it's initialization into Sriov binding driver initialization?

sounds good, I agree
so do we have to check if instance of Sriov Binding Driver exists?
But as I understand initialization on line 282 happens before drivers initialization , isn't it?
umm, I wonder if we can at least check if the multivif driver is enabled. That is needed for SRIOV right?

that is why I'm asking. This is the point where everything is initialized, but pod_resources_client is only needed for sriov driver. So, I would still leave it here but make it optional depending on the drivers configured, what do you think?

I'm still not completely happy with always initialiting this. Perhaps on the clients side we can check if sriov config options are set (i.e., the kubelet_root_dir) or have an specific disabled option), and if not just return None in this function instead of calling PodResourcesClient init

regarding you suggestion, Ilia left good comment

    My 2 cents: clients.setup_pod_resources_client() will never fail, because gRPC client properly handles the missing unix socket case. Failure will happen if you'll try to use it, i.e. if you will try to get the list of pod resources. Another point is that, IMHO, we should not allow using SRIOV if pod-resources is not available because this will lead to unpredictable device assignments as described in the bug. So,

    if user has PodResources disabled (or kubelet version < 1.13) and doesn't try to use SRIOV, everything will be fine.
    if user has PodResources disabled and will try to use SRIOV, there will be gRPC exception and CNI will fail the port binding. Isn't it a normal behavior?
    if user has PodResources enabled and doesn't try to use SRIOV, everything is fine. Just a slight memory overhead on gRPC client.
    if user has PodResources enabled and will try to use SRIOV, this is our main case, everything should be OK.

so I'm not sure if we should add special check one more time. If you really want to add check of kubelet_root_dir in config in client.py, we can do it

I would still prefer to have something on the setup_pod_resource_client() that skips the initialization is kubelet_root_dir is not set. This way we have a way to 'disable' it, not just having it enable always but failing if used
kubelet_root_dir has a default value, so it's always set.

Other projects (ironic for example) are sticking with py3. Adding py37 is a stretch goal so I interpret that as optional.

I mostly did it because these are the default tox settings when you run the tests for local dev. Zuul doesn't care about this list.

I got sick of seeing red for versions of python not on our systems. 'py3' just made local testing easier, and then Zuul (or even our internal ci) picks specific environments it wants to run in.

I may remove 'py36,py37' and just stick with 'py3' for the default list. Or if the overall recommendation is to be explicit we should remove 'py3'. I'm inclined to just use 'py3' for the default unless there is a good reason otherwise.

tempest/lib/api_schema/response/volume/c.message:
This does not seem correct for 2 reasons:

1) The example lists many more possible properties: https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html#id438
2) The description indicates: "The backend volume capabilities list, which is consisted of cinder standard capabilities and vendor unique properties." Vendor unique properties means that this would have to be extensible, i.e. support many key-value pairs.

This shows the formatting: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/7f7716d584cd955162cab988c49c6fa3ac08f2e0/cinder/api/views/capabilities.py#L30

It is called here: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/7f7716d584cd955162cab988c49c6fa3ac08f2e0/cinder/api/contrib/capabilities.py#L56

Note that because of .get(field_name) I'm not sure if all of the ones below can be 'string', 'null' for the 'type' (except for properies and replication_targets).
.get(field_name) means the field is not optional, but not necessarily means its value can't be null?

You're right. .get() means the field is "required" but not necessarily populated with a non-null value. If a dict or something doesn't have a key then .get(key) will return None by default so it could be null but this isn't easy to tell from code.
This one can be: regex='^OS::Storage::Capabilities::.+$' (see: 'OS::Storage::Capabilities::%s' % id)
This one should have 11 fields as per code above, missing: 'description'
nit: May be good to expand on this with more schema definition here with a TODO comment. The docs don't make it clear what goes into this array.

'namespace' is optional according to API docs: https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html#id440 but according to https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/7f7716d584cd955162cab988c49c6fa3ac08f2e0/cinder/api/views/capabilities.py#L31 it is always returned so API docs need to be fixed Cinder side.

specs/rocky/generic-push-driver.rst.message: im not sure, i have raised this before, but still im not sure, is remove operation really needed, for real time policy evaluation , instead why cant we use PUT instead which is way simpler to use. Did you get any usecases for patch operation?

Yup you've brought it up before on the implementation review. Here's the discussion: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/535009/2//COMMIT_MSG@56

Here's an example that illustrates:

Let's say we have a rule that says to migrate a VM if there are at least two alarms raised on the VM. If one alarm is raised on the VM (say high disk latency) and then 10 min later another alarm is raised on the VM (say high dropped packets), now there are two alarms on the VM so the congress rule should be triggered.

If only PUT is available, then at the time the second alarm is raised the sender must gather both alarms and PUT both of them to Congress, because if only the second alarm is PUT, then the first alarm (still active) is erased from Congress and the rule fails to trigger.

But many sources are not built to send the entire state, only the new change. Vitrage is an example. I think many other notifiers are similarly designed to send new info not entire state. Hence the need for PATCH add instead of just PUT.

Similar example illustrates the need for remove.

Say we have a rule that identifies all "green" resources (no active alarms). Let's consider the same VM now with two active alarms.
Then let's say the dropped packets alarm went away but the disk latency alarm remains. The source wants to send to Congress that the dropped packets alarm has gone away, but without a remove operation and without a snapshot, it can't correctly send the change information.

As for supporting differential update with PUT, how do you envision it working? And how is it different/better than PATCH?

>> For PUT , what i meant is suppose i have pushed data based on notification to congress, as soon as data is pushed corresponding policy gets evaluated right. Now, if there is simultaneous request to push different data , there might be scenario , before the previous data gets evaluated , it will be replaced, so im thinking of how about we can add only differential change instead of whole replacement?
>> scenario might be rare case, but let me know ur opinion

Definitely helpful to think through edge cases.
Here's how Congress would handle the situation.

As long as Congress receives the first snapshot before the second snapshot, policy evaluation would take place on the first snapshot before the data is replaced by the second snapshot. This is guaranteed because each PUT call triggers a publish from the congress data source, which is sequenced and guaranteed to be processed in order by the policy engine. The policy engine makes sure to finish evaluating policy after each publish it receives before moving on to process another publish.

Of course, if the second PUT snapshot gets to Congress before the first, then the second PUT will be processed first. If we have an important use case where we need to make sure API requests arriving out-of-order gets re-ordered, then we'd need to implement some kind of sequencing or resource barrier.

Differential update doesn't really solve the problem. But if differential update is desired, PATCH or POST can be used. We don't support POST right now, but I think we need to for Monasca push update.

There's more to discuss on the Monasca push update. This particular spec is doing a row-oriented generic push data driver. But Monasca I think requires a object-oriented model which is more complex to do in a generic way. So my thinking is that we'll do that first in a monasca specific way in monasca driver, then maybe in the future extend to a generic object-oriented push driver.

I see. So I think you're wondering whether data from previous updates may be stale/out-of-date and shouldn't be relied on?
Say maybe when the second alarm comes in, at that point the first alarm has already been deactivated, but by relying on previous updates Congress then does something incorrect?

In that case what we expect is that the source sends a PATCH:remove update on the first alarm when it deactivated.

Basically, Congress offers a set of operations with well-defined semantics for the source to use to communicate state to Congress. And it's up to the source to tell Congress what to do to accurately reflect the latest state. If the source wants congress to delete all previous data and only take the new (because previous data no longer valid), then it would use PUT. If the source wants Congress to delete certain pieces of previous data, it would use PATCH:remove. If the source wants Congress to delete some and add some, then it would use PATCH with a sequence of operations. It's not up to Congress to guess what happens to previously given data.

Now a particular use case may call for evaluating policy on only recent data say within 60 seconds. To accomplish that in a policy-oriented way, I think the source should include a timestamp column, and then the policy writer would write the Congress policy to include a condition that it considers only those rows with a timestamp column within the last 60 seconds (using the datetime builtins in the Congress rule language).

To make it easier, we could consider adding in the generic data source driver an option to add an implied timestamp column (future work?). That way we can get an approximate timestamp even if the source doesn't natively support sending it.

Furthermore, if we want data deleted from Congress after a certain amount of time, I think a policy-oriented way to do it would be to write a condition-action rule that identifies rows with older time stamps and triggers a PATCH:remove action to Congress. I think Congress currently doesn't support calling its own actions through policy, but we can add that if desired.

But Im confused , whenever the data is pushed , say when first alarm is raised, evaluation of policy happens immediately right, so that particular row shouldnt get evaluated ideally when second alarm is triggered?

And sending only new change is fine, but my concern is how valid is to evaluate all the data again and again , which seems to happen in this case.

may be i misunderstood scenario here, please clarify.

For PUT , what i meant is suppose i have pushed data based on notification to congress, as soon as data is pushed corresponding policy gets evaluated right. Now, if there is simultaneous request to push different data , there might be scenario , before the previous data gets evaluated , it will be replaced, so im thinking of how about we can add only differential change instead of whole replacement?
scenario might be rare case, but let me know ur opinion

and also could you add cli part , how to use this driver,
first datasource needs to be created and then first add , and subsequent operation update or so? it will provide some clarity on usage

zuul/cmd/executor.py.message: does this need to be sort of registered for the shutdown path (in executor/server.py)?  otherwise maybe this jumps in an kills the executor when it's shutting down?

The way the fork is done below that race should be avoided. The child log streamer process waits for the parent's pipe to close then shuts itself down. That should avoid this race. However, if we want belts and suspenders for this we can add a stop flag that the shutdown of the executor sets.
I agree that we should include stopping this into the shutdown procedure. Otherwise there could be a race where this kicks in and terminates the executor non-gracefully.
I think we should try to gracefully stop the executor to give it a chance to abort all jobs. As a fallback we can still directly exit after a grace period.

It feels a bit like we're mixing ideas here ... the log streaming process is sitting in a read() on the pipe to notice if the parent dies.  but here we're checking with a waitpid() and sleep...

if the child didn't close pipe_write, and we just did pipe_write.read() here for the blocking?  when that returns, the same checks for a shutdown situation v unexpected can occur?

I know this is working with what we have ... I hesitate to descend into bikeshedding but this now does seem like we've replicated what the multiprocessing package provides?  with the shutdown changes here, it seems like with multiprocessing you could start the child and then just join() it, then once that join() returns check the shutdown flag and if it's not set, die (unexpected) or if it is, just ignore?

openstack/watcher/openstack-watcher-api..message: Are you sure that watcher API support SD_NOTIFY? I couldn't find it in the source.

Looks liek it does.

Watcher uses oslo_service.

https://opendev.org/openstack/watcher/src/branch/master/watcher/cmd/api.py#L26
https://opendev.org/openstack/watcher/src/branch/master/watcher/common/service.py

And oslo_service support SD_NOTIFY.

https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.service/src/branch/master/oslo_service/systemd.py
This needs to be in the [Service] section

On a second thought, I think we should remove it from the unit file. Reason is watchter-db-manage is depending on the DB configuration in watcher-api.conf, which we don't have at the time of package installation. We should let configuration management (i.e. chef, ansible, etc) to handle to that.

I would like to keep it because:
- We also have it in other packages (if we decide to remove it, let's remove it everywhere)
- it does not hurt if it fails because of the =-
- it's not about package installation. you can install the package, configure the DB connection and then start the systemd service. That's totally valid and you don't need any chef/ansible/salt

openstack/watcher/openstack-watcher-appl.message: I think having it in the openstack-watcher-api.service is enough.
Yes. Make sense. Seem like it has a soft dependency on openstack-watcher-api.service. I'll add that.

openstack/watcher/openstack-watcher-deci.message: Do all of these services all need to run the db upgrade? For cinder, glance, and nova we only run it for the API service. If all of these services are trying to run the db upgrade at startup there could be a db lock.
I tend to agree, I find it strange that nova, glance and cinder do this.

I'd hate to spoil a +2, but should we really run the db upgrade in a service file at all? After all people usually go to great lengths to only run that sort of thing on exactly one controller node in multi controller environments. Having that step hardwired in a service file sounds like a surefire recipe for setting people who run multi controller deployments up for a well hidden race condition.
